sentence.value: Hans Wilhelm Schlegel (Überlingen, 3 August 1951) is a German physicist, an ESA astronaut, and a veteran of two NASA Space Shuttle missions.
sentence.annotated-sentence: [[Hans Wilhelm Schlegel|Hans_Schlegel]] ([[Überlingen|%C3%9Cberlingen]], [[3 August|August_3]] [[1951|1951]]) is a [[German|Germany]] [[physicist|Physicist]], an [[ESA|European_Space_Agency]] [[astronaut|Astronaut]], and [[a veteran|Veteran]] of two [[NASA|NASA]] [[Space Shuttle missions|List_of_space_shuttle_missions]].
sentence.pattern_crowdsource: [[Hans Wilhelm Schlegel|Hans_Schlegel]] ([[Überlingen|%C3%9Cberlingen]], 3 August 1951) is a [[German|Germany]] [[physicist|Physicist]], an ESA [[astronaut|Astronaut]], and a veteran of two NASA Space Shuttle missions.

sentence.value: Schlegel, born and raised in Germany, graduated as an international exchange student from Lewis Central High School in Council Bluffs, Iowa before studying physics at RWTH Aachen University in his home country.

sentence.value: After having received his university degree, he conducted research in semiconductor physics before being trained as an astronaut in the late 1980s by the German Aerospace Center (DLR).

sentence.value: He flew as a DLR payload specialist in 1993 aboard Space Shuttle mission STS-55, which included the German-sponsored Spacelab D-2 research module.

sentence.value: From 1995 to 1997, he trained as the backup crew member for the German-Russian Mir'97 mission, and afterwards received additional training in Russia to become qualified as a second board engineer for the Mir space station.

sentence.value: The mission was charged with the responsibility of putting the Columbus laboratory in orbit, in addition to its connection to the International Space Station.
